intro: Oncoba eximia, commonly known as the Florida hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a deciduous shrub that typically grows in wetlands and along the edges of freshwater habitats. The plant produces showy, pink to red flowers that bloom in the summer months. Its leaves are ovate and have a rough, hairy texture, while its stems are woody and often branched. Oncoba eximia plays an important ecological role by providing nectar for pollinators and habitat for various wildlife species.
